Catalog.name: SecurityAnalysisResult
Catalog.Note: The Security Analysis Result (SAR) profile is a profile to exchange a security analysis result.

The security analysis result includes each limit violation detected for each assessed element and for a given contingency. The limit violation has a direct association to operational limit and contingency. The association to the operational limit provides information on the following:
- The terminal (the end of the equipment) where the limit is defined
- The equipment to which the limit is related
- The type of the limit e.g. PATL, TATL, etc including the relevant time phase and other conditions
The association to the contingency provides information which contingency was simulated when this limit violation was detected.

This profile is not intended to replace the Topology (TP) and State Variables (SV) profiles. Its intention is to exchange a power flow result that is relevant for security optimization, either through violation or through a loading threshold. Systems should not use this profile for dumping a full database. The modeling is optimized to have the minimum size in addition to a well defined value definition (e.g. active power, apparent power, etc.).

Recommendation: If the terminals are connected with zero impedance, it is recommended to include only one terminal with a voltage (e.g. the terminal of a BusbarSection). The connection between Contingency and Remedial Action is given by the Remedial Action Profile. The connection between AssessedElement and PowerFlowResult is given by the OperationalLimit.

ComplexType.name: ACDCTerminal
ComplexType.Comment: An electrical connection point (AC or DC) to a piece of conducting equipment. Terminals are connected at physical connection points called connectivity nodes.

Root.name: BaseCasePowerFlowResult
Root.Comment: Base case power flow result for a given terminal.

Root.name: Breaker
Root.Comment: A mechanical switching device capable of making, carrying, and breaking currents under normal circuit conditions and also making, carrying for a specified time, and breaking currents under specified abnormal circuit conditions e.g. those of short circuit.

ComplexType.name: ConductingEquipment
ComplexType.Comment: The parts of the AC power system that are designed to carry current or that are conductively connected through terminals.

ComplexType.name: ConnectivityNodeContainer
ComplexType.Comment: A base class for all objects that may contain connectivity nodes or topological nodes.

ComplexType.name: Contingency
ComplexType.Comment: An event threatening system reliability, consisting of one or more contingency elements.

Root.name: ContingencyPowerFlowResult
Root.Comment: Contingency power flow result on a given terminal for a given contingency.

Instance.name: Contingency
Instance.Comment: The contingency that has this power flow result.

InverseInstance.name: ContingencyPowerFlowResult
InverseInstance.Comment: The power flow result that is associated with a contingency.

Root.name: Cut
Root.Comment: A cut separates a line segment into two parts. The cut appears as a switch inserted between these two parts and connects them together. As the cut is normally open there is no galvanic connection between the two line segment parts. But it is possible to close the cut to get galvanic connection.

The cut terminals are oriented towards the line segment terminals with the same sequence number. Hence the cut terminal with sequence number equal to 1 is oriented to the line segment's terminal with sequence number equal to 1.

The cut terminals also act as connection points for jumpers and other equipment, e.g. a mobile generator. To enable this, connectivity nodes are placed at the cut terminals. Once the connectivity nodes are in place any conducting equipment can be connected at them.

Domain.name: lengthFromTerminal1
Domain.Comment: The length to the place where the cut is located starting from side one of the cut line segment, i.e. the line segment Terminal with sequenceNumber equal to 1.

Root.name: DisconnectingCircuitBreaker
Root.Comment: A circuit breaking device including disconnecting function, eliminating the need for separate disconnectors.

Root.name: Disconnector
Root.Comment: A manually operated or motor operated mechanical switching device used for changing the connections in a circuit, or for isolating a circuit or equipment from a source of power. It is required to open or close circuits when negligible current is broken or made.

ComplexType.name: Equipment
ComplexType.Comment: The parts of a power system that are physical devices, electronic or mechanical.

Simple.name: inService
Simple.Comment: Specifies the availability of the equipment. True means the equipment is available for topology processing, which determines if the equipment is energized or not. False means that the equipment is treated by network applications as if it is not in the model.

Simple.name: normallyInService
Simple.Comment: Specifies the availability of the equipment under normal operating conditions. True means the equipment is available for topology processing, which determines if the equipment is energized or not. False means that the equipment is treated by network applications as if it is not in the model.

ComplexType.name: EquipmentContainer
ComplexType.Comment: A modelling construct to provide a root class for containing equipment.

Root.name: GroundDisconnector
Root.Comment: A manually operated or motor operated mechanical switching device used for isolating a circuit or equipment from ground.

ComplexType.name: IdentifiedObject
ComplexType.Comment: This is a root class to provide common identification for all classes needing identification and naming attributes.

Simple.name: mRID
Simple.Comment: Master resource identifier issued by a model authority. The mRID is unique within an exchange context. Global uniqueness is easily achieved by using a UUID, as specified in RFC 4122, for the mRID. The use of UUID is strongly recommended.
For CIMXML data files in RDF syntax conforming to IEC 61970-552, the mRID is mapped to rdf:ID or rdf:about attributes that identify CIM object elements.

EnumeratedValue.name: alarmVoltage
EnumeratedValue.Comment: Voltage alarm.

EnumeratedValue.name: highVoltage
EnumeratedValue.Comment: Referring to the rating of the equipments, a voltage too high can lead to accelerated ageing or the destruction of the equipment.
This limit type may or may not have duration.

EnumeratedValue.name: lowVoltage
EnumeratedValue.Comment: A too low voltage can disturb the normal operation of some protections and transformer equipped with on-load tap changers, electronic power devices or can affect the behaviour of the auxiliaries of generation units.
This limit type may or may not have duration.

EnumeratedValue.name: operationalVoltageLimit
EnumeratedValue.Comment: Operational voltage limit.

EnumeratedValue.name: patl
EnumeratedValue.Comment: The Permanent Admissible Transmission Loading (PATL) is the loading in amperes, MVA or MW that can be accepted by a network branch for an unlimited duration without any risk for the material.

The OperationnalLimitType.isInfiniteDuration is set to true. There shall be only one OperationalLimitType of kind PATL per OperationalLimitSet if the PATL is ApparentPowerLimit, ActivePowerLimit, or CurrentLimit for a given Terminal or Equipment.

EnumeratedValue.name: patlt
EnumeratedValue.Comment: Permanent Admissible Transmission Loading Threshold (PATLT) is a value in engineering units defined for PATL and calculated using a percentage less than 100 % of the PATL type intended to alert operators of an arising condition. The percentage should be given in the name of the OperationalLimitSet. The aceptableDuration is another way to express the severity of the limit.

EnumeratedValue.name: stability
EnumeratedValue.Comment: Stability.

EnumeratedValue.name: tatl
EnumeratedValue.Comment: Temporarily Admissible Transmission Loading (TATL) which is the loading in amperes, MVA or MW that can be accepted by a branch for a certain limited duration.
The TATL can be defined in different ways:
<ul>
• as a fixed percentage of the PATL for a given time (for example, 115% of the PATL that can be accepted during 15 minutes),
<ul>

• pairs of TATL type and Duration calculated for each line taking into account its particular configuration and conditions of functioning (for example, it can define a TATL acceptable during 20 minutes and another one acceptable during 10 minutes).
Such a definition of TATL can depend on the initial operating conditions of the network element (sag situation of a line).
The duration attribute can be used to define several TATL limit types. Hence multiple TATL limit values may exist having different durations.

EnumeratedValue.name: tc
EnumeratedValue.Comment: Tripping Current (TC) is the ultimate intensity without any delay. It is defined as the threshold the line will trip without any possible remedial actions.

The tripping of the network element is ordered by protections against short circuits or by overload protections, but in any case, the activation delay of these protections is not compatible with the reaction delay of an operator (less than one minute).
The duration is always zero if the OperationalLimitType.acceptableDuration is exchanged. Only one limit value exists for the TC type.

EnumeratedValue.name: tct
EnumeratedValue.Comment: Tripping Current Threshold (TCT) is a value in engineering units defined for TC and calculated using a percentage less than 100 % of the TC type intended to alert operators of an arising condition. The percentage should be given in the name of the OperationalLimitSet. The aceptableDuration is another way to express the severity of the limit.

EnumeratedValue.name: warningVoltage
EnumeratedValue.Comment: Voltage warning.

Root.name: Location
Root.Comment: The place, scene, or point of something where someone or something has been, is, and/or will be at a given moment in time. It can be defined with one or more position points (coordinates) in a given coordinate system.

Simple.name: direction
Simple.Comment: (if applicable) Direction that allows field crews to quickly find a given asset. For a given location, such as a street address, this is the relative direction in which to find the asset. For example, a streetlight may be located at the 'NW' (northwest) corner of the customer's site, or a usage point may be located on the second floor of an apartment building.

Root.name: OperationalLimit
Root.Comment: A value and normal value associated with a specific kind of limit.
The sub class value and normalValue attributes vary inversely to the associated OperationalLimitType.acceptableDuration (acceptableDuration for short).

If a particular piece of equipment has multiple operational limits of the same kind (apparent power, current, etc.), the limit with the greatest acceptableDuration shall have the smallest limit value and the limit with the smallest acceptableDuration shall have the largest limit value. Note: A large current can only be allowed to flow through a piece of equipment for a short duration without causing damage, but a lesser current can be allowed to flow for a longer duration.

Instance.name: OperationalLimitSet
Instance.Comment: The limit set to which the limit values belong.

Instance.name: OperationalLimitType
Instance.Comment: The limit type associated with this limit.

InverseInstance.name: OperationalLimit
InverseInstance.Comment: The operational limits associated with this type of limit.

EnumeratedType.name: OperationalLimitDirectionKind
EnumeratedType.Comment: The direction attribute describes the side of a limit that is a violation.

EnumeratedValue.name: absoluteValue
EnumeratedValue.Comment: An absoluteValue limit means that a monitored absolute value above the limit value is a violation.

EnumeratedValue.name: high
EnumeratedValue.Comment: High means that a monitored value above the limit value is a violation. If applied to a terminal flow, the positive direction is into the terminal.

EnumeratedValue.name: low
EnumeratedValue.Comment: Low means a monitored value below the limit is a violation. If applied to a terminal flow, the positive direction is into the terminal.

Root.name: OperationalLimitSet
Root.Comment: A set of limits associated with equipment. Sets of limits might apply to a specific temperature, or season for example. A set of limits may contain different severities of limit levels that would apply to the same equipment. The set may contain limits of different types such as apparent power and current limits or high and low voltage limits that are logically applied together as a set.

Instance.name: Terminal
Instance.Comment: The terminal where the operational limit set apply.

InverseInstance.name: OperationalLimitSet
InverseInstance.Comment: The operational limit sets at the terminal.

Root.name: OperationalLimitType
Root.Comment: The operational meaning of a category of limits.

Domain.name: acceptableDuration
Domain.Comment: The nominal acceptable duration of the limit. Limits are commonly expressed in terms of the time limit for which the limit is normally acceptable. The actual acceptable duration of a specific limit may depend on other local factors such as temperature or wind speed. The attribute has meaning only if the flag isInfiniteDuration is set to false, hence it shall not be exchanged when isInfiniteDuration is set to true.

Simple.name: isInfiniteDuration
Simple.Comment: Defines if the operational limit type has infinite duration. If true, the limit has infinite duration. If false, the limit has definite duration which is defined by the attribute acceptableDuration.

Enumerated.name: kind
Enumerated.Comment: Types of limits defined in the ENTSO-E Operational Handbook Policy 3.

ComplexType.name: PowerFlowResult
ComplexType.Comment: Power flow result including any operational limit violation.

Simple.name: absoluteValue
Simple.Comment: Absolute value from a power flow calculation on a given terminal related to a given operational limit. For instance, if the operational limit is 1000 A and the current flow is 1100 A the absoluteValue is reported as 1100 A.

Simple.name: atTime
Simple.Comment: The date and time of the scenario time that was studied and at which the limit violation occurred.

Simple.name: isViolation
Simple.Comment: True if the power flow result is violating the associated operational limit. False if it is not violating the associated operational limits.

Domain.name: value
Domain.Comment: The value of the limit violation in percent related to the value of the operational limit that is violated. For instance, if the operational limit is 1000 A and the current flow is 1100 A the value is reported as 110 %.

Domain.name: valueA
Domain.Comment: Current from a power flow calculation on a given terminal. The value shall be a positive value or zero.

Domain.name: valueAngle
Domain.Comment: Voltage angle value from a power flow calculation on a given terminal.

Domain.name: valueV
Domain.Comment: Voltage value from a power flow calculation on a given terminal. The attribute shall be a positive value.

Domain.name: valueVA
Domain.Comment: Apparent power value from a power flow calculation on a given terminal.

Domain.name: valueVAR
Domain.Comment: Reactive power value from a power flow calculation on a given terminal.
Load sign convention is used, i.e. positive sign means flow out from a TopologicalNode (bus) into the conducting equipment.

Domain.name: valueW
Domain.Comment: Active power value from a power flow calculation on a given terminal.
Load sign convention is used, i.e. positive sign means flow out from a TopologicalNode (bus) into the conducting equipment.

Reference.name: ACDCTerminal
Reference.Comment: ACDC terminal where the powerflow result is located.

InverseReference.name: PowerFlowResult
InverseReference.Comment: Power result associated with the ACDC terminal.

Instance.name: OperationalLimit
Instance.Comment: The operational limit that has this limit violation.

InverseInstance.name: PowerFlowResult
InverseInstance.Comment: The limit violation associated with an operational limit.

Reference.name: ReportedByRegion
Reference.Comment: The region which reports this limit violation.

InverseReference.name: LimitViolation
InverseReference.Comment: The limit violation reported by a region.

ComplexType.name: PowerSystemResource
ComplexType.Comment: A power system resource (PSR) can be an item of equipment such as a switch, an equipment container containing many individual items of equipment such as a substation, or an organisational entity such as sub-control area. Power system resources can have measurements associated.

ComplexType.name: ProtectedSwitch
ComplexType.Comment: A ProtectedSwitch is a switching device that can be operated by ProtectionEquipment.

Domain.name: breakingCapacity
Domain.Comment: The maximum fault current a breaking device can break safely under prescribed conditions of use.

Root.name: Recloser
Root.Comment: Pole-mounted fault interrupter with built-in phase and ground relays, current transformer (CT), and supplemental controls.

ComplexType.name: Region
ComplexType.Comment: A region where the system operator belongs to.

ComplexType.name: RemedialAction
ComplexType.Comment: Remedial action describes one or more actions that can be performed on a given power system model situation to eliminate one or more identified breaches of constraints. The remedial action can be costly, and have a cost characteristic, or non costly.

Root.name: RemedialActionApplied
Root.Comment: Remedial Action or Remedial Action Stage that has been applied to the power flow case which has the associated power flow result.

Simple.name: mRID
Simple.Comment: Master resource identifier issued by a model authority. The mRID is unique within an exchange context. Global uniqueness is easily achieved by using a UUID, as specified in RFC 4122, for the mRID. The use of UUID is strongly recommended.
For CIMXML data files in RDF syntax conforming to IEC 61970-552, the mRID is mapped to rdf:ID or rdf:about attributes that identify CIM object elements.

Instance.name: PowerFlowResult
Instance.Comment: Power flow result that is obtained when the remedial action is applied.

InverseInstance.name: RemedialActionApplied
InverseInstance.Comment: Remedial action that is applied when the power flow result is calculated.

InverseInstance.name: RemedialActionApplied
InverseInstance.Comment: The relationship of the applied remedial action and power flow result.

Instance.name: StageForRemedialActionScheme
Instance.Comment: The stage of the remedial action scheme that is applied.

InverseInstance.name: RemedialActionApplied
InverseInstance.Comment: The applied relationship between remedial action and a power flow result.

ComplexType.name: Stage
ComplexType.Comment: Stage of a remedial action scheme.

CompoundType.name: Status
CompoundType.Comment: Current status information relevant to an entity.

Simple.name: dateTime
Simple.Comment: Date and time for which status 'value' applies.

Simple.name: reason
Simple.Comment: Reason code or explanation for why an object went to the current status 'value'.

Simple.name: remark
Simple.Comment: Pertinent information regarding the current 'value', as free form text.

Simple.name: value
Simple.Comment: Status value at 'dateTime'; prior status changes may have been kept in instances of activity records associated with the object to which this status applies.

CompoundType.name: StreetAddress
CompoundType.Comment: General purpose street and postal address information.

Simple.name: language
Simple.Comment: The language in which the address is specified, using ISO 639-1 two digit language code.

Simple.name: poBox
Simple.Comment: Post office box.

Simple.name: postalCode
Simple.Comment: Postal code for the address.

CompoundType.name: StreetDetail
CompoundType.Comment: Street details, in the context of address.

Simple.name: addressGeneral
Simple.Comment: First line of a free form address or some additional address information (for example a mail stop).

Simple.name: addressGeneral2
Simple.Comment: (if applicable) Second line of a free form address.

Simple.name: addressGeneral3
Simple.Comment: (if applicable) Third line of a free form address.

Simple.name: buildingName
Simple.Comment: (if applicable) In certain cases the physical location of the place of interest does not have a direct point of entry from the street, but may be located inside a larger structure such as a building, complex, office block, apartment, etc.

Simple.name: code
Simple.Comment: (if applicable) Utilities often make use of external reference systems, such as those of the town-planner's department or surveyor general's mapping system, that allocate global reference codes to streets.

Simple.name: floorIdentification
Simple.Comment: The identification by name or number, expressed as text, of the floor in the building as part of this address.

Simple.name: name
Simple.Comment: Name of the street.

Simple.name: number
Simple.Comment: Designator of the specific location on the street.

Simple.name: prefix
Simple.Comment: Prefix to the street name. For example: North, South, East, West.

Simple.name: suffix
Simple.Comment: Suffix to the street name. For example: North, South, East, West.

Simple.name: suiteNumber
Simple.Comment: Number of the apartment or suite.

Simple.name: type
Simple.Comment: Type of street. Examples include: street, circle, boulevard, avenue, road, drive, etc.

Simple.name: withinTownLimits
Simple.Comment: True if this street is within the legal geographical boundaries of the specified town (default).

Root.name: Substation
Root.Comment: A collection of equipment for purposes other than generation or utilization, through which electric energy in bulk is passed for the purposes of switching or modifying its characteristics.

ComplexType.name: Switch
ComplexType.Comment: A generic device designed to close, or open, or both, one or more electric circuits. All switches are two terminal devices including grounding switches. The ACDCTerminal.connected at the two sides of the switch shall not be considered for assessing switch connectivity, i.e. only Switch.open, .normalOpen and .locked are relevant.

Simple.name: normalOpen
Simple.Comment: The attribute is used in cases when no Measurement for the status value is present. If the Switch has a status measurement the Discrete.normalValue is expected to match with the Switch.normalOpen.

Simple.name: open
Simple.Comment: The attribute tells if the switch is considered open when used as input to topology processing.

Domain.name: ratedCurrent
Domain.Comment: The maximum continuous current carrying capacity in amps governed by the device material and construction.
The attribute shall be a positive value.

Simple.name: retained
Simple.Comment: Branch is retained in the topological solution. The flow through retained switches will normally be calculated in power flow.

CompoundType.name: TownDetail
CompoundType.Comment: Town details, in the context of address.

Simple.name: code
Simple.Comment: Town code.

Simple.name: country
Simple.Comment: Name of the country.

Simple.name: name
Simple.Comment: Town name.

Simple.name: section
Simple.Comment: Town section. For example, it is common for there to be 36 sections per township.

Simple.name: stateOrProvince
Simple.Comment: Name of the state or province.

EnumeratedType.name: UnitMultiplier
EnumeratedType.Comment: The unit multipliers defined for the CIM. When applied to unit symbols, the unit symbol is treated as a derived unit. Regardless of the contents of the unit symbol text, the unit symbol shall be treated as if it were a single-character unit symbol. Unit symbols should not contain multipliers, and it should be left to the multiplier to define the multiple for an entire data type.

For example, if a unit symbol is "m2Pers" and the multiplier is "k", then the value is k(m**2/s), and the multiplier applies to the entire final value, not to any individual part of the value. This can be conceptualized by substituting a derived unit symbol for the unit type. If one imagines that the symbol "" represents the derived unit "m2Pers", then applying the multiplier "k" can be conceptualized simply as "k".

For example, the SI unit for mass is "kg" and not "g". If the unit symbol is defined as "kg", then the multiplier is applied to "kg" as a whole and does not replace the "k" in front of the "g". In this case, the multiplier of "m" would be used with the unit symbol of "kg" to represent one gram. As a text string, this violates the instructions in IEC 80000-1. However, because the unit symbol in CIM is treated as a derived unit instead of as an SI unit, it makes more sense to conceptualize the "kg" as if it were replaced by one of the proposed replacements for the SI mass symbol. If one imagines that the "kg" were replaced by a symbol "", then it is easier to conceptualize the multiplier "m" as creating the proper unit "m", and not the forbidden unit "mkg".

EnumeratedValue.name: k
EnumeratedValue.Comment: Kilo 10**3.

EnumeratedValue.name: m
EnumeratedValue.Comment: Milli 10**-3.

EnumeratedValue.name: none
EnumeratedValue.Comment: No multiplier or equivalently multiply by 1.

EnumeratedType.name: UnitSymbol
EnumeratedType.Comment: The derived units defined for usage in the CIM. In some cases, the derived unit is equal to an SI unit. Whenever possible, the standard derived symbol is used instead of the formula for the derived unit. For example, the unit symbol Farad is defined as "F" instead of "CPerV". In cases where a standard symbol does not exist for a derived unit, the formula for the unit is used as the unit symbol. For example, density does not have a standard symbol and so it is represented as "kgPerm3". With the exception of the "kg", which is an SI unit, the unit symbols do not contain multipliers and therefore represent the base derived unit to which a multiplier can be applied as a whole.

Every unit symbol is treated as an unparseable text as if it were a single-letter symbol. The meaning of each unit symbol is defined by the accompanying descriptive text and not by the text contents of the unit symbol.

To allow the widest possible range of serializations without requiring special character handling, several substitutions are made which deviate from the format described in IEC 80000-1. The division symbol "/" is replaced by the letters "Per". Exponents are written in plain text after the unit as "m3" instead of being formatted as "m" with a superscript of 3 or introducing a symbol as in "m^3". The degree symbol "" is replaced with the letters "deg". Any clarification of the meaning for a substitution is included in the description for the unit symbol.

Non-SI units are included in list of unit symbols to allow sources of data to be correctly labelled with their non-SI units (for example, a GPS sensor that is reporting numbers that represent feet instead of meters). This allows software to use the unit symbol information correctly convert and scale the raw data of those sources into SI-based units.
The integer values are used for harmonization with IEC 61850.

EnumeratedValue.name: A
EnumeratedValue.Comment: Current in amperes.

EnumeratedValue.name: V
EnumeratedValue.Comment: Electric potential in volts (W/A).

EnumeratedValue.name: VA
EnumeratedValue.Comment: Apparent power in volt amperes. See also real power and reactive power.

EnumeratedValue.name: VAr
EnumeratedValue.Comment: Reactive power in volt amperes reactive. The reactive or imaginary component of electrical power (VIsin(phi)). (See also real power and apparent power).

Note: Different meter designs use different methods to arrive at their results. Some meters may compute reactive power as an arithmetic value, while others compute the value vectorially. The data consumer should determine the method in use and the suitability of the measurement for the intended purpose.

EnumeratedValue.name: W
EnumeratedValue.Comment: Real power in watts (J/s). Electrical power may have real and reactive components. The real portion of electrical power (I²R or VIcos(phi)), is expressed in Watts. See also apparent power and reactive power.

EnumeratedValue.name: deg
EnumeratedValue.Comment: Plane angle in degrees.

EnumeratedValue.name: none
EnumeratedValue.Comment: Dimension less quantity, e.g. count, per unit, etc.

SimpleType.name: ActivePower
SimpleType.Comment: Product of RMS value of the voltage and the RMS value of the in-phase component of the current.

SimpleType.name: ApparentPower
SimpleType.Comment: Product of the RMS value of the voltage and the RMS value of the current.

SimpleType.name: CurrentFlow
SimpleType.Comment: Electrical current with sign convention: positive flow is out of the conducting equipment into the connectivity node. Can be both AC and DC.

SimpleType.name: Length
SimpleType.Comment: Unit of length. It shall be a positive value or zero.

SimpleType.name: PerCent
SimpleType.Comment: Percentage on a defined base. For example, specify as 100 to indicate at the defined base.

Simple.name: value
Simple.Comment: Normally 0 to 100 on a defined base.

SimpleType.name: ReactivePower
SimpleType.Comment: Product of RMS value of the voltage and the RMS value of the quadrature component of the current.

Simple.name: value
Simple.Comment: Time, in seconds

SimpleType.name: Voltage
SimpleType.Comment: Electrical voltage, can be both AC and DC.

PrimitiveType.name: Boolean
PrimitiveType.Comment: A type with the value space "true" and "false".

PrimitiveType.name: DateTime
PrimitiveType.Comment: Date and time as "yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm:ss.sss", which conforms with ISO 8601. UTC time zone is specified as "yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm:ss.sssZ". A local timezone relative UTC is specified as "yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm:ss.sss-hh:mm". The second component (shown here as "ss.sss") could have any number of digits in its fractional part to allow any kind of precision beyond seconds.

PrimitiveType.name: Float
PrimitiveType.Comment: A floating point number. The range is unspecified and not limited.

PrimitiveType.name: String
PrimitiveType.Comment: A string consisting of a sequence of characters. The character encoding is UTF-8. The string length is unspecified and unlimited.

Package.name: Base
Package.Comment: Content of the base CIM published as IEC 61970-301.

Package.name: Common
Package.Comment: This package contains the information classes that support distribution management in general.

Package.name: Contingency
Package.Comment: Contingencies to be studied.

Package.name: Core
Package.Comment: Contains the core PowerSystemResource and ConductingEquipment entities shared by all applications plus common collections of those entities. Not all applications require all the Core entities. This package does not depend on any other package except the Domain package, but most of the other packages have associations and generalizations that depend on it.

Package.name: DetailedModelDescription
Package.Comment: This clause packages classes needed to describe a model for dynamics simulations. This approach enables parties to exchange user defined model description expressed as mathematical expressions. It can also be used to describe standard models. Different profiles that use this information model shall make a choice of language used to describe the equations. The model enables creation of two separate profiles:
1) a profile to describe the detailed model configuration, and
2) a profile to enable an exchange of parameters of the model described using profile defined in 1).

Package.name: Domain
Package.Comment: The domain package defines primitive datatypes that are used by classes in other packages. Stereotypes are used to describe the datatypes. The following stereotypes are defined:
<<enumeration>> A list of permissible constant values.
<<Primitive>> The most basic data types used to compose all other data types.

<<CIMDatatype>> A datatype that contains a value attribute, an optional unit of measure and a unit multiplier. The unit and multiplier may be specified as a static variable initialized to the allowed value.
<<Compound>> A composite of Primitive, enumeration, CIMDatatype or other Compound classes, as long as the Compound classes do not recurse.
For all datatypes both positive and negative values are allowed unless stated otherwise for a particular datatype.

Package.name: Dynamics
Package.Comment: The CIM dynamic model definitions reflect the most common IEEE or, in the case of wind models, IEC, representations of models as well as models included in some of the transient stability software widely used by utilities.

These dynamic models are intended to ensure interoperability between different vendors software products currently in use by electric utility energy companies, utilities, Transmission System Operators (TSOs), Regional Transmission Organizations (RTOs), and Independent System Operators (ISOs). It is important to note that each vendor is free to select its own internal implementation of these models. Differences in vendor results, as long as they are within accepted engineering practice, caused by different internal representations, are acceptable.
Unless explicitly stated otherwise, the following modelling conventions are followed:
- limited integrators are of the non-windup type;
- it shall be possible to enter a time constant of zero (where it makes sense).
The information in the entire clause "Common Information Model Dynamics package" is reproduced from the UML with the permission of UCAIug.

Package.name: EuropeanCIMExtensions
Package.Comment: The package contains the European extensions to canonical CIM model.

Package.name: ExtArea
Package.Comment: This package contains the extensions related to the areas.

Package.name: ExtEuBase
Package.Comment: This package contains the European extensions to Base package of the canonical CIM model.

Package.name: ExtEuOperationalLimits
Package.Comment: European extensions to OperationalLimits package.

Package.name: ExtIEC61970
Package.Comment: This package contains the European extensions to IEC61970 package of canonical CIM model.

Package.name: ExtNetworkCodes
Package.Comment: This package contains the extensions defined for the need of Network codes (NC) data exchanges.

Package.name: ExtRemedialAction
Package.Comment: This package contains the extensions related to the remedial action.

Package.name: ExtSIPS
Package.Comment: This package contains the extensions related to the SIPS which is a kind of remedial action scheme. A remedial action scheme can have different stages. Each stage represents the change of values of one element in the grid model compared to the base case is described by the grid state alteration. Each stage can have multiple triggers that have a priority and one or many conditions. When the condition (gate) is reached, the grid state alteration is activated.
A remedial action scheme is a kind of a remedial action. In this way, the remedial action scheme participates in the optimization of the remedial actions.

Package.name: ExtSecurityAnalysisResult
Package.Comment: This package contains the extensions related to the security analysis result.

Package.name: IEC61968
Package.Comment: The IEC 61968 subpackages of the CIM are developed, standardized and maintained by the UCA community including its working groups and task forces.
Currently, normative parts of the model support the needs of information exchange defined in IEC 61968-3, IEC 61968-4, IEC 61968-5, IEC 61968-6, IEC 61968-8, IEC 61968-9 and in IEC 61968-13.

Package.name: IEC61970
Package.Comment: Top package for IEC 61970.

Package.name: InfEuropeanCIMExtensions
Package.Comment: Informative European CIM extensions.

Package.name: OperationalLimits
Package.Comment: This package models a specification of limits associated with equipment and other operational entities.

Package.name: TC57CIM
Package.Comment: Top package for IEC TC57 CIM.

Package.name: Wires
Package.Comment: An extension to the Core and Topology package that models information on the electrical characteristics of Transmission and Distribution networks. This package is used by network applications such as State Estimation, Load Flow and Optimal Power Flow.
